page.title: Questions - Main Clause Yes/No Questions
page.introduction: In English, main clause Yes/No questions are formed by moving an auxiliary verb in front of the subject. Other languages use a Yes/No question marker or special complementizer instead of the fronted auxiliary. (English does this in embedded Yes/No quesrions.) English examples of main clause Yes/No questions are:

EnglishExample.exItem: Are you going to the store?
Will Sue buy the present for her mother?
Could the boy have hit the ball?

radioGroup.prompt: For main clause Yes/No questions, does your language have one or more Yes/No question markers or complementizers (include affixes or clitics in answering this question)?
Is it written as a separate word?
radioGroup.radio: No, it is an affix or clitic which attaches to another word

radioGroup.prompt: Is the clitic a proclitic (prefix) or an enclitic (suffix)?
Where does the clitic attach to the Yes/No question?
Where does the Yes/No question marker occur with respect to the rest of the question?
radioGroup.radio: Either side, but not both sides at the same time
On either side, or on both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the Yes/No question markers appear on either side of the question?
radioGroup.radio: No, there are separate sets for each side
No, but an auxiliary is fronted, like in English

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the auxiliary occur with respect to the rest of the question?

radioGroup.radio: No, there is no marker or word order change in main clause Yes/No questions, just a difference in intonation or tone or other non-syntactic marking

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ to these clitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ_prefix to these clitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ_suffix to these clitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, add the feature YNQ_prefix to the proclitics and add YNQ_suffix to the enclitics. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, if this word does not already have the category C, add the feature makeC to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. (If a particular entry can also be used as another syntactic category, make a separate lexical entry for each use.) In either case, add the feature question. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, do not add any root feature.

In the lexicon, mark those markers which can only occur initially with the feature CP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature CP-final. Do not enter either feature on any markers which can occur on either side.
